704109f-a.title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - 19th Street (East)
704109f-a.text:
Emmons Ave., north side, at, adjoining and east of East 19th Street.
The 3-story frame building in the foreground, is still standing. All the
other buildings were razed to make way for the New Lundy Restaurant in 1934.
July 6, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.

702633f.title: Brooklyn: 19th Street (East) - Emmons Avenue
702633f.text:
East 19th Street, west side, at, adjoining and north of Emmons Ave.
The view of the 3-story frame building has changed; in 1934 stores were
built in front and the entrance to the Grill is on East 19th Street.
July B, 1933.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
(2)
The same, showing at the N.E. corner the Sheepshead Bay house in 1857;
the John McMahon Hotel in 1873. This hotel was leased in December 1924
by the McMahon Estate to the Laudme Holding Company (Lundy Bros.) who
converted it into quabters for waiters employed in the Lundy Restaurant.
December 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.
(3)
The same, when it was known as the Tamaqua Yacht Club.
January 1924.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
MAY BE REPRODUCED.

702634f.title: Brooklyn: 19th Street (East) - Emmons Avenue
702634f.text:
East 19th Street, west side, north from the N.W. corner of Emmons
Ave. One of the many parking spaces in Sheepshead Bay.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.
NO REPRODUCTIONS.
